I'm a little baffled by Blair's stance in the whole issue. Charles Clarke was gearing up for compromise following consultation with the Torys and Lib Dems (which seemed quite savvy and likely to save face for the Government) but the same day Tony threw his full clout in public behind getting the full 90 day detention clause into law. Now, there are several reasons he might have done this:
 
 1) He misunderstood the size of the rebellion he was facing and thought the bill would carry through. If this had happened his authority would have been enhanced having given such strong public backing to the position prior to the vote.
 
 2) He knew how big the rebellion was (quite possible given there was a three line party whip on the vote) but thought lending his personal authority to the matter in a public matter would bring enough rebellious backbenchers to heel to carry the legislation.
 
 3) Having being through a generally bad patch in terms of his leadership since the invasion of Iraq he thought this was a vote to support because of the public opinion on the matter and backing it received from the Police, hence boosting his popularity.
 
 The likelyhood of defeat seems to have become clear shortly before the vote as evidenced by the recall of several high profile ministers to try sway the rebels. Unfortunately for Blair he has done himself significant damage though his unwillingness to accept Clarke's compromise vote for 28 days detention (which would have passed, as opposed to handing victory to the back bench amendment vote for 28 days) as he has lost his first commons vote (the rebels will be buoyed as they now know they can win if put to fight) he politcised the Police with his arguements (who also loose much face as it was made very clear how much they wanted 90 day detention by the PM) and off course has undermined his authority as leader of the Labour party.
 
 Blairs rejection of sound advice from one of his Ministers reminds me of the situation prior to the invasion of Iraq. The forigen Secretary Jack Straw strongly advised against any UK involvement in Iraq- Blair won that vote using the 45 minute claim but subsequent events have shown what a bad choice going into Iraq was.
 
 At the end of the day for me its the end of the line for Blairs brand of "I believe this is the right thing to do" style of politics. Such a style can only take someone so far and eventually facts and reason have to support a position.

Sometimes we hear him saying he will serve a full third term, but I also struggle to see him doing so as Brown will need time to assert his authority over the party and establish himself as the new leader in the public eye prior to a very challenging General Election.
 
 Could further defeats hasten Blair departure? difficult to say- here the fragile unity between Brown and Blair will be key as Brown could challenge Blair at anytime before the next election if he so chose. Blair winning such a contest would be a loose-loose result for the Labour Party. If Blair does suffer further defeats on legislation Brown's position will strengthen and his supporters will extert ever more pressure on Blair to step aside. Would Blair be prepared do so 2-3 years before the next election? if not then an open contest could be on the cards intsead of a dignified exit (a thing that Blair wants- he does not want to end his leadership as Margaret Thatcher did hers).

 All in all Blair is in for the most testing time of hs Premiership- his own position is on the line in a way it has not been previously.
